importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the latest public awareness and advocacy efforts regarding the detention of Mohammed Ibrahim, highlighting ongoing international concern over the treatment of minors in Israeli detention.

The start of the Gaza war is referenced as a backdrop to the worsening conditions in Israeli prisons, including the deaths of Palestinian detainees, which intensified scrutiny of Israeli detention practices.

This date is tied to the killing of two US citizens in the West Bank by Israeli forces, raising concerns about the safety of American citizens in conflict zones and the broader implications for US-Israel relations and diplomatic leverage.

Since 2022, Israeli forces have killed at least 10 US citizens, including two in the West Bank, indicating a pattern of violence that may influence international pressure on Israel and US policy responses.
Mohammed Ibrahim was detained in February 2025 during a raid on his family’s home in the West Bank, marking the beginning of his detention and the onset of the reported mistreatment.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from February 2025 to October 2025 covers the duration of Mohammed Ibrahim’s detention, during which he has endured harsh conditions, weight loss, and deteriorating health, forming a critical timeframe for human rights advocacy.

This period includes the Gaza war, during which Palestinian detainees have suffered severe medical neglect and abuse, contributing to the broader context of systemic human rights violations in Israeli detention facilities.

keyTakeAways: Mohammed Ibrahim, a 16-year-old Palestinian American boy, is being held in Israeli detention since February 2025, facing severe physical and psychological abuse including cold cells, meagre meals, and denial of medical care.
The US government, including Congress and the Trump administration, has been urged to use diplomatic pressure to secure his release, despite his status as a US citizen.
Israel is the only country that systematically prosecutes children in military courts, raising global human rights concerns.
Mohammed’s case has become a symbol of the mistreatment of minors in Israeli jails, with documented reports of beatings, inadequate food, and lack of heating or cooling.
At least 79 Palestinian detainees have died in Israeli prisons since October 2023 due to poor medical care, food restrictions, and violence, underscoring systemic abuse.
Legal experts and human rights groups assert that Palestinians in occupied West Bank areas rarely receive fair trials in Israeli military courts.
Mohammed's father and family have repeatedly called on the US government to intervene, emphasizing that even a US passport cannot protect a child in Israeli custody.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Mohammed Ibrahim, a 16-year-old Palestinian American boy, has been detained in Israeli prisons since February 2025 after a military raid on his family’s home in the West Bank. He has described severe mistreatment, including cold cells, minimal and nutritionally inadequate meals, denial of heating or cooling, and physical abuse during transport. Despite being a US citizen, he remains in detention, with human rights groups and US lawmakers, including Congresswoman Ayanna Pressley and Defense for Children International – Palestine (DCIP), urging the Trump administration to use diplomatic pressure to secure his release. The case has become a symbol of the broader systemic mistreatment of children in Israeli military courts, where Palestinians are routinely denied fair trials. This is compounded by reports of deaths among Palestinian detainees since October 2023 and the recent Gaza ceasefire, which intensified global calls for his release. The article underscores a critical global human rights issue: the treatment of minors in Israeli detention, even when they are citizens of a foreign country.
title: Cold cells, meagre meals: Palestinian American boy suffers in Israeli jail
